values.comments:
Management 104 focuses on the economic and institutional constraints on organizations in the formulation and implementation of human resources management policies and strategies in the United States and, as appropriate, internationally. The specific constraints discussed are labor markets (external and internal), labor laws (governing employment policies and employee relations), and labor unions (and the threat thereof). Particular attention is paid to the relationship of these constraints to the competitiveness of American enterprise in the global economy.

Overall, students were strongly divided in their opinions of the class. Some students described the class as “very good” or “very interesting” but many others described it as the “worst class” that they had taken at Penn. The class was structured around small group discussions. Some students felt that the group set-up “helped [them] learn more” and was “very effective,” but others said it was “a complete waste of time” and “not conducive to learning.” Additionally, about half of the students found the class to be “very interesting,” felt that it taught “useful topics,” and praised the “open-ended” nature of assignments that enabled “students to explore their interests.” The other half described the class as “boring” and complained that they “learned little if anything of substance.” A number of students commented that Professor Barankay was “still experimenting” and that the class was “highly disorganized” and “very impromptu.”

Students were also starkly divided in their opinions of Professor Barankay. Some described him as an “excellent,” “engaging” instructor who was “entertaining and [made] class fun and interesting.” However, many students also complained that during class discussions, “there [was] clearly an answer he [had] in mind” and that “students’ answers would be dismissed if they did not answer exactly what he wanted.” Several said that he seemed to “be frustrated with the students.” A number of other students noted that Professor Barankay did “not express an interest in getting to know students,” and others described him as “confusing” and “boring.” A number of students also expressed concerns that Professor Barankay placed “too much emphasis on his own research material.”

Students reported that class participation was a large part of the grade, which a couple cited as problematic as Professor Barankay had “no idea who anyone [was].” One student said that the class was “really easy” and “required little to no work” although another noted that “reading the texts [was] important to participate in class.” A couple students had complaints about the final project saying that it had “conflicting guidelines” and created “much confusion on behalf of all students” and that grading was “unfair.” One student commented that the “exams [were] very rushed,” and another said that Professor Barankay “seem[ed] like a very subjective grader but [did] seem to value effort to learn the material.” Management 104 is one of two classes that can be taken to fulfill Wharton’s Organizational Environment requirement. The prerequisites are MGMT 100 and MGMT 101.
